head.supplied: 3/11/81. ¶ ¶ Before the thought passes from my mind, dear Prof. Tate, I like to mention to you, that it has never been ascertained, what Euc. diversifolia of Bonpland is, who raised it from seeds of ...

div.p: Barr Smith Library, University of Adelaide, SA.

Before the thought passes from my mind, dear Prof. Tate, I like to mention to you, that it has never been ascertained, what Euc. diversifolia of Bonpland is, who raised it from seeds of Baudin's Expedition, gathered in Kangaroo-Island.
SA. As the lower leaves are ovate and opposite and the upper alternate or scattered, it may be a young state of an alternate-leaved species. The flowers are 5-8 in a head. There ought to be no difficulty of getting specimens from your K. I.'s correspondents, at all events fruit-specimens, as fruits are to be found on Eucalypts all the year round. We shall probably have to discard the name of some other Eucalypt, to bring that of Bonplands to honor again.
M was right! E. santalifolia, which he himself had named in 1854 from specimens found at the Murray River and St Vincent and Spencer Gulfs, SA, is now regarded as the same as Bonpland's species, and M's name has sunk into synonmy. See also M to R. Tate, 7 November 1881.
Anyhow it is very desirable, that your friends on the Island should pay early & special attention to the Eucalypts .
I have not heard from the Rev. Mr. Kempe for a long time. So there must be also drought in his district.

Surely the S.A. Government is sending out a small Camel-party to the actual death-place of Leichhardt in your territory, to erect a small monumental cairn, & bury the bones of the unfortunates.
explain.
You could have there no abler man than Mr Tietkens, for such a holy mission as Mr Giles is otherwise engaged. Can you take up this cause.
